subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] why  'why'?
msgSnippet: ... Minimal pairs are by definition not homophones but differ in one sound each only: _beat_ [bit] and _Pete_ [pit] are not the same word, and therefore /b/
messageBody:
On 2007-12-12 Paul Tremblay wrote:
> What happens if there are a lot of minimal pairs in a
> language, but they happened to be all homophones

Minimal pairs are by definition not homophones but differ
in one sound each only: _beat_ [bit] and _Pete_ [pit] are
not the same word, and therefore /b/ and /p/ are phonemes
of English.

However a pair of words which is a minimal pair for the
speakers of one accent may be a pair of homophones for the
speakers of another accent where the two sounds have merged
(or failed to split, but that's more unusual), and that's
what happens with _wear_ and _where_ which are a minimal
pair /wEr/ vs. /WEr/ in accents which have not gone through
W-WH-merger, but homophonous /wEr/ in those accents which
have gone through that merger (which happens to be the
majority).

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
